snippet: Some of California’s biggest water users — including Beverly Hills, Newport Beach and Palos Verdes — would have to cut their water consumption by 35 percent under the terms of a preliminary plan.
abstract: California's State Water Resources Control Board issues plan to meet mandatory 25 percent reduction in statewide water use, with some communities required to reduce their water intake by as much as 35 percent while others face cutbacks of just 10 percent; cuts point to fact that many communities, particularly in Southern California, have failed to voluntarily curtail use at time of severe drought.

byline.original: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
byline.contributor: Adam Nagourney reported from Los Angeles, and Emma G. Fitzsimmons from San Francisco.

lead_paragraph: Some of California’s biggest water users — including Beverly Hills, Newport Beach and Palos Verdes — would have to cut their water consumption by 35 percent under the terms of a preliminary plan.

headline.main: Under New Water Rules, Beverly Hills Must Turn Off Taps; Santa Cruz, Less So
headline.print_headline: Anemic Report on Conservation Adds to California Water Crisis
